channel.name: How can I detect the chain in the SmartContract method?

messages.content: I need to check the signature using the SmartContract method. I want to ensure that the signature created for the Berkeley testnet cannot be used on the mainnet so I will include chainId in the signed data. How can I detect the chain in the method? It seems like this.network doesn't have this information.
You could simply store the information in a field in the smart contract
The smart contract can’t verify it but people who use it can
So the front end would fail if it’s incorrectly set
The smart contract would simply disallow changing the field after deployment
But yes I don’t think there’s a good way of checking the network you’re on, if there’s any at all
I don't want to use one of the 8 Fields. I understand that I can as an alternative to change the contract by changing some constants, but I am looking for a more elegant solution.
It’s possible you can do something crazy with the protocol state hash and receipt chain hash preconditions though but this is simpler
Just hardcode it then
Use a different vk for different networks
Frontend needs to check if vk hash is correct anyway
Finally, after looking into available options one more time, I've decided to hardcode it. I will change the code when deploying to the mainnet.

@DFST `Mina.getNetworkId()`

@Las something to note: the vk is already necessarily different for a contract deployed to mainnet than one deployed to testnet. that's because the chainid is encoded into the account update hash that every method performs
Where is that chain id?
In preconditions?
it's not part of the tx - it defines the prefix for the account update hash. so it's a constant which is used in the circuit of every zkapp method

every zkapp method (at least when you use o1js) does the following:
* create an account update
* hash it and check that the hash equals the public input
and this computation features the chain id as a hard-coded constant
@gregor so when O1JS compiles a circuit, does it fetch this from graphql?
And network id is chain id?

It works, but I have to do string manipulations inside the SmartContract as NetworkId returned by Mina.getNetworkId() is a string 'testnet' or 'mainnet' (there should be 'zeko', 'lightnet', 'testworld2' probably?):
```typescript
const id = CircuitString.fromString(Mina.getNetworkId().toString()).hash();
proof.publicInput.decision.chainId.assertEquals(id); 
```
Is there a more elegant way to check networkId inside the SmartContract without string manipulations?
Maybe it makes sense to add hash property to the NetworkId, similar to the VerificationKey?

> there should be 'zeko', 'lightnet', 'testworld2' probably?
you can set it to a custom value different than testnet/mainnet with
```ts
let instance = Mina.Network({ networkId: { custom: "zeko" }, ...otherConfig });
```
it has to be set by the user when defining the Mina instance ^^
Oh lol
Albeit I checked and allegedly GraphQL exposes signatureKind, which ought to be what should be used?

> there should be 'zeko', 'lightnet', 'testworld2' probably?
@DFST but note that this is just for protecting against replays of test txn on mainnet. So you don't need a different one for every testnet
yeah good idea to fetch it!
You shouldn’t have to do string manipulation, you ought be able to do that out of circuit
Yes, but soon there will be a Zeko mainnet, so we will have at least two mainnets (with more coming as Zeko appchains)

> You shouldn’t have to do string manipulation, you ought be able to do that out of circuit
I mean it creates a constant, so it kinda is out of circuit
yep that's true. that's why "custom" was added!
This would also make O1JS work with Zeko OOB
I would be glad if you could maybe implement it some time
ah ok! but can't we also just tell users what to set it to when using zeko?
Yeah but it’s more work
ok, if you could post it as an issue would be nice so we don't forget
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1492

embeds.title: Fetch `networkId` automatically from GraphQL endpoint · Issue #1492...
embeds.description: That way when using custom networks you don't have to set the salt for both account update hashing and signatures manually.
